etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Henry Watts (1815–1884), chemist. From ancient Greek πορϕύρα purple + -ine, after German Porphyrin

definitions: An amorphous alkaloid, C₂₁ H₂₅ N₃ O₂, obtained from the bark of the Australian tree Alstonia constricta (family Apocynaceae), which produces a red colour on reaction with nitric acid.
